article:
A 'galactoside' is a glycoside containing galactose. The H of the OH group on
carbon-1 of galactose is replaced by an organic moiety.

Depending on whether the glycosidic bond lies "above" or "below" the plane of
the galactose molecule, galactosides are classified as Î±-galactosides or Î²-
galactosides.

A Î²-galactoside is a type of galactoside in which the glycosidic bond lies above
the plane of the galactose residue. The most commonly recognized and used Î²-
galactoside in biochemistry is lactose. However, other chemicals, such as ONPG,
are known, but these are typically synthesized for biochemical assays. An enzyme
that breaks the Î²-galactoside bond is called a Î²-galactosidase.
